metadata.title: Activity and stability of titanosilicate supported Au catalyst for propylene epoxidation with H<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> and O<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf>

Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Epoxidation of propylene over titanosilicate supported Au catalyst as a function of time-on-stream. Reaction conditions: Catalyst, 0.15 g; Temperature, 300 °C; Feed gas, C3H6/O2/H2/Ar = 1/1/1/7 (vol%); Space velocity, 7000 mL gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 FT-IR spectra of PO adsorbed on titanosilicate supported Au catalyst at 300 °C: flushing in PO 1 h, then vacuum pumping 1 h. Fig. 13 Fig. 14 FT-IR spectra of propylene adsorbed on titanosilicate supported Au catalyst at 300 °C: flushing in propylene 1 h, then vacuum pumping 1 h. Activity and stability of titanosilicate supported Au catalyst for propylene epoxidation with H2 and O2 Sainan Yao a Luhang Xu a Jing Wang a Xiaoliang Jing b Tareque Odoom-Wubah a Daohua Sun a Jiale Huang a ⁎ Qingbiao Li a b c ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 PR China b College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Quanzhou Normal University, Quanzhou, 362000, PR China College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Quanzhou Normal University Quanzhou 362000 PR China c Environmental Science Research Center, College of the Environment & Ecology, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China Environmental Science Research Center College of the Environment & Ecology Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China. Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 PR China Graphical abstract Highly dispersed Au catalysts supported on amorphous titanosilicate supports with three-dimensional wormhole-like mesoporosity were prepared by deposition–precipitation method, which show excellent performance in propylene epoxidation with H2 and O2. The best catalytic performance, propylene conversion of 12.8%, propylene oxide selectivity of 76.2% and PO space-time yield of 160.9 gpo/Kgcat/h, was obtained at the reaction temperature of 300 °C. The Ti/Si molar ratio of the supports and some experimental parameters, such as the urea amount, loading temperature and Au loading on the as-produced catalyst are optimized. In addition, with the assistance of in-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (In-situ FT-IR), adsorption and desorption of PO, propylene and the reaction mixture on the catalyst are conducted to further explore the deactivation mechanism. It suggests that propylene and PO can be irreversibly and strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface and finally transform to carbonate adsorbed on the active sites Ti-OH, resulting in catalyst deactivation. Keywords Titanosilicate Au catalyst Propylene epoxidation Stability Deactivation mechanism 1 Introduction Propylene oxide (PO) is an important and versatile organic intermediate for production of various raw materials such as polyether polyols, polyurethane and propylene glycol [1]. Currently, PO is industrially produced by the chlorohydrin, co-oxidation and HPPO (H2O2 oxidation) processes [1]. Nevertheless, the chlorinated by-products from the chlorohydrin process pose severe pollution problems. For the co-oxidation process, the co-products such as tert-butyl alcohol and styrene have a negative effect on the economic effectiveness. As far as the HPPO process is concerned, the successful process combines the production of H2O2 through anthraquinone hydrogenation and subsequent epoxidation of propylene with H2O2. However, the HPPO process depends strongly on the adjacent H2O2 plant. The vapor-phase epoxidation of propylene with co-reactants H2 and O2 (as abundant, flexible and preferable raw gases) over highly dispersed Au nanoparticles (NPs) has been regarded as a promising alternative to the above processes [2–5]. Since propylene epoxidation with PO selectivity of above 90% in the presence of H2 and O2 over Au NPs (measuring 2–5 nm) deposited on anatase TiO2 was demonstrated by Hayashi et al. [2], a great deal of effort has been devoted to the vapor-phase propylene epoxidation in the past few decades [3,6–9]. It has been reported that the Au NPs are required to highly cooperate with the tetrahedrally coordinated Ti4+ sites in the catalyst for the vapor-phase propylene epoxidation [10,11]. Hence, Au catalysts supported on various titanium-containing supports such as TiO2, TiO2/SiO2, TS-1, Ti-TUD, Ti-SBA-15, Ti-MCM-41, Ti-MCM-48, and Ti-MWW etc. [6,8,9,11–16] have been investigated for the propylene epoxidation. It is commonly believed that the catalytic activity of Au catalysts is greatly affected by their preparation methods [17–19]. The deposition–precipitation (DP) method using sodium hydroxide (DP NaOH), which was developed by Haruta et al. [20], has been frequently adopted to prepare highly active Au NPs (measuring 2–3 nm) catalysts for the propylene epoxidation [21]. However, it was found that the gold NPs in solution cannot be completely deposited on the support [21], leading to the low Au utilization efficiency [7,22]. In contrast, the DP method using urea (DP urea) offers a simpler and cheaper route for preparation of supported Au catalysts with higher Au capture efficiency and better catalytic performance [21,23–25]. This is due to the fact that the pH value of the synthesis suspension can increase slowly via the hydrolysis of urea. Accordingly, the Au can be completely deposited onto the support [21,23,26]. However, there is still a common unsolved problem, i.e. the unstable catalytic performance and rapid deactivation of the Au catalysts [27]. Ruiz et al. [28] proposed that the adsorbed propylene on Au/TiO2 can be converted into acrylate, which was further transformed to formate and carbonate covering the active sites of the catalyst. Moreover, bidentate propoxy species were another intermediate responsible for the catalysts deactivations which were produced by the ring-opening reaction of PO. However, the deactivation mechanism of Au catalysts supported on titanosilicate has remained unclear so far. In this work, a series of Au catalysts supported on amorphous titanosilicate with three-dimensional wormhole-like mesoporosity (Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalysts) were prepared by DP urea method. The effects of support structure and preparation conditions for the catalysts on the catalytic performance were investigated. Furthermore, the deactivation mechanisms of the Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalysts for propylene epoxidation were studied by in-situ FT-IR analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of titanosilicate supports The amorphous titanosilicate supports (named meso-Ti-O-Si) with three-dimensional wormhole-like mesoporosity were synthesized following the modified sol-gel method reported by Sinha et al. [29]. The supports with a Si-Ti molar ratio of 50 was prepared by the following steps: First, 0.7 g titanium butoxide (TBOT) was added dropwise to 20.8 g tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) under stirring at room temperature. Next, 29.8 g triethanolamine (TEA) was added and then 19.8 g deionized water was added dropwise to the stirring mixture. The mixture was further stirred for 1.5 h, and then 16.8 g 40% tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) was added dropwise to the solution. Thereafter, the homogeneous mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then dried overnight at 100 °C. Last, the dried mixture was calcined at 700 °C for 10 h at a ramp rate of 1 °C min−1 under air atmosphere. Different Si/Ti molar ratios were tuned by changing the amount of titanium (IV) tetrabutoxide (TBOT, 99 wt%). The synthesized meso-Ti-O-Si with Si/Ti molar ratio of n is labeled as meso-Ti-O-Si-n. 2.2 Deposition of Au Au NPs were deposited on the supports by DP urea method. The detail preparations are given as follows: The titanosilicate supports (0.5 g) was added to 50 ml of an aqueous solution (the Au3+/urea molar ratio of 1:10) with 0.0076 g urea and 260 uL HAuCl4 (0.04856 mol L−1), and then the resulting mixture was stirred for 4 h at 60 °C. After that, the solids were separated from the precursor solution by filtration and washed 4 times with deionized water. The obtained samples were dried at 50 °C for 1 h and then calcined at 300 °C for another 1 h in a muffle furnace at a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1 under air flow. The theoretical and practical Au loadings of prepared catalysts were very close, i.e. 0.50 wt%, as complete deposition was validated in the light of no Au leaching in the filtrate. The catalysts were named by xAu/meso-Ti-O-Si-y in which x and y denotes gold loading and Si/Ti molar ratio, respectively. For instance, 0.5Au/meso-Ti-O-Si-50 represents a catalyst with gold loading of 0.5 wt% and Si/Ti molar ratio of 50. 2.3 Characterization of supports and Au catalysts X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on an X’Pert Pro X-ray Diffractometer with CuKα as radiation (40 kV, 30 mA) in the scanning range of 10–90°. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was measured on a Nicolet 6700 with DTGS room temperature sensor, where the supports were ground with KBr. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRUV–vis) of samples were performed in the range of 200–800 nm with a Varian Cary 5000 spectrophotometer, using BaSO4 as the reference. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy of the liquid samples were taken on an UNICAM UV-300 spectrophotometer from 330 to 800 nm at room temperature, which was used to detect the existence of Au3+ in the filtration liquid. BET surface area analysis of supports through N2 adsorption isotherms was measured with the Micromeritics Tristar 3000 surface area analyzer, after samples outgassing under vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of Au catalysts were obtained from a Tecnai F30 microscope. Size distribution of Au NPs was determined with the previous method [30]. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted on a Netzsch TG209F1 thermobalance. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests The catalytic performance of the supported Au catalysts were measured with a vertical fixed-bed stainless-steel reactor (half-inch), using a feed of C3H6/O2/H2/N2 (volumetric ratio: 1/1/1/7) passed over the catalyst (150 mg) bed at a space velocity of 7000 h−1 cm−3/g catalyst, where reaction gas flows were measured with bubble flow meters. The Au catalysts were kept at 573 K for the reaction. Reaction temperature was monitored by a glass tubular covered Cr-Al thermocouple located inside the catalyst bed. The reactants and products were analyzed online with two gas chromatographs equipped with TCD (MS 5A and Porapak Q column) and FID detector (Porapak T column). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance and characterizations of the supported Au catalysts In order to understand the effect of preparation conditions on the catalytic performance of Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalysts by DP urea method, the catalysts were prepared by adjusting the Si/Ti molar ratios, urea amount, preparation temperature and Au loading. Table 1 shows the catalytic activities of the Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalysts with different preparation conditions for propylene epoxidation. Among them, the 0.50Au/meso-Ti-O-Si-50 catalyst that had been in bold font given in Table 1 had optimal catalytic activity. 3.1.1 Effect of the Si/Ti molar ratios Ti4+ has been demonstrated to play a critical role in propylene epoxidation [31]. Ti4+ combines with hydrogen peroxide formed by H2 and O2 on gold sites to generate 6-coordinated Ti–OOH (η2) species, which is demonstrated to be important active intermediates for propylene epoxidation [32]. It can be seen from the DRUV–vis spectra (Fig. S3) in the Supporting Information(SI) and the catalytic performance in Table 1 that the PO space-time yield was closely associated with Ti4+ concentration. At the Si/Ti molar ratio of 25, the CO2 selectivity increased because of the Ti-O-Ti structure, while CO2 was substantially produced as the main product at the Si/Ti molar ratio of 10, which was attributed to the presence of a large amount of isolated TiO2. Therefore, the Ti-O-Ti structure and segregated TiO2 had a negative effect on PO generation due to severe deep oxidation, especially in the presence of TiO2. 3.1.2 Effect of the urea amount Fig. 1 shows UV–vis spectra of undiluted filtrates with different urea amount through changing the molar ratio of Au3+/urea during catalyst preparation. The intensity of the absorption peaks (at 289 nm due to Au3+) determined whether Au3+ loaded completely on the supports or not. As shown in Fig. 1, no Au3+ exists in the undiluted filtrates of the catalyst in which urea has been added. ICP-MS was also employed to measure Au actual loading of those catalysts. The results showed that the actual loadings of all urea-added catalysts are above 0.495%, which is consistent with the UV–vis results. However, the absence of urea results in the remnant of Au3+ in the filtrates. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images and corresponding histograms of size distribution of Au NPs in the catalysts prepared with different urea amount. As shown, the Au NPs obtained by urea precipitation dispersed evenly while the particle size is significantly smaller and the size distribution narrower than those without urea. In terms of the characterization (Figs. 1 and 2) and catalytic performance (Table 1), it should be noted that the catalysts prepared by urea precipitation shows better catalytic activity than those without urea precipitation. It can be attributed to complete precipitation of Au3+, high dispersion, smaller size and narrower size distribution of Au NPs. In addition, with an increase of the urea amount, the Au particle size gradually decreases. When the molar ratio of Au3+/urea is 1/100, the particle size distribution of Au NPs measuring less than 2 nm could not be estimated accurately. It has been reported [33] that the hydrogenation of propylene usually prevails over Au clusters smaller than 2.0 nm (in the absence of alkalis). Therefore, the catalytic activity markedly decreased after the amount of urea increased to Au3+/urea of 1/100 (molar ratio). Therefore, the urea amount mainly affects the Au3+ deposition and the size of Au NPs on the surface of supports, which further affects the catalytic performance. 3.1.3 Effect of loading temperature According to the UV–vis spectra of undiluted filtrates at different loading temperatures (40 °C, 60 °C, 80 °C, 90 °C) during catalysts preparation, as shown in Fig. 3 , it can be observed that Au3+ cannot load completely on the support at 40 °C (Fig. 3a), but almost complete loading can be achieved in the other three cases (Fig. 3b–d), which thereby increases the active sites of the catalysts and enhances the catalytic activity (Table 1). Sequentially the size of Au NPs decreases slightly, when the loading temperature is increased to 80 °C, as shown in the TEM images in Fig. 4 . This can inhibit some side reactions and simultaneously slightly increase PO selectivity. However, the much smaller Au NPs may be unfavorable to the reaction, leading to decrease of the propylene conversion. When the loading temperature rises to 90 °C, the Au NPs size becomes even smaller. Meanwhile, it can be seen from the DRUV–vis spectra (Fig. 5 ) of the catalysts that a large number of Ti-O-Ti structures at about 308 nm were generated on account of the transformation of isolated Ti, leading to substantial decline of the propylene conversion and PO selectivity. 3.1.4 Effect of Au loading The UV–vis spectra of filtrates (Fig. 6 ) shows the intensity of residual Au3+ bands at around 289 nm gradually increases as Au theoretical loading increases. In other words, the maximum Au loading of catalyst was reached due to the limited specific surface area of the supports. Combined with the catalyst performance in Table 1, it can be proposed that increasing Au loading can increase the active sites of the catalysts to some extent. As a result, the catalytic activity can be improved. However, excessive Au loading may cover the active Ti4+ sites, which was detrimental to the catalytic performance. At the same time, as shown in the TEM images (Fig. 7 ), at the extremely high Au loading, the Au particle size was larger because of the agglomeration of Au NPs, which is detrimental to the propylene epoxidation. Hence, proper Au loading was essential to the propylene epoxidation. 3.2 Catalyst stability It has been previously reported that propylene epoxidation over Au catalysts suffered from rapid deactivation [34]. On one hand, the deactivation can be attributed to the agglomeration of Au NPs. On the other hand, deposition of carbonous species on the catalyst surface might block the active epoxidation sites. The stability of 0.50Au/meso-Ti-O-Si-50 catalyst in 170 h at 300 °C and space velocity of 7000 mL gcat−1 h−1 was investigated and the catalytic activity is shown in Fig. 8 . It can be seen that PO selectivity remained stable. However, after reaction of about 40 h, propylene conversions began to decline while PO space-time yield went downward, indicating the occurrence of the deactivation. The fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by TG and TEM, respectively. As shown in Fig. 9 (A), compared with the catalyst without reaction, there was a significant weight loss peak at about 470 °C for the catalyst after reaction of 170 h, which was ascribed to the feed or products adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. As can be seen from the TEM images (Fig. 9B and C) of the catalyst, Au NPs did not agglomerated and remained the same particle size (2.5 ± 0.4 nm) after the long time reaction, which showed that the possibility of Au NPs agglomeration was excluded for significant deactivation of the catalyst. Hence, severe carbon deposition on the catalyst surface may be vital for the catalyst deactivation. 3.3 Catalysts deactivation mechanism 3.3.1 Adsorption of propylene oxide To further investigate the reasons why carbon deposited on the catalysts, in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy was used to study the interaction of PO, propylene and propylene/O2/H2 mixture with the catalysts, respectively. The spectra obtained after PO adsorption (adsorption time of 60 min) and subsequent desorption in N2 at 573 K in the in-situ cell are shown in Fig. 10 . The interaction between PO and the catalyst was completely irreversible. Since the spectrum of Au/meso-Ti-O-Si was used as background, decreasing of intensities show as negative bands. Three negative bands at 3733 cm−1, 3690 cm−1 and 3541 cm−1 in the 4000–3200 cm−1 region remained after 40 min of N2 flow. The 3733 cm−1 and 3690 cm−1 bands have previously been assigned to Si-OH and Ti-OH site of the support surface, respectively [35–37]. Therefore, there were species adsorbed on Ti-OH and Si-OH site. It has been reported that the interaction between PO and the catalysts will cause bidentate propoxy species, which may be adsorbed on Ti-OH and Si-OH sites [35]. The other negative band located at 3541 cm−1 can be assigned to silanol nests at defect sites of supports [37]. That is, part of silanol nests at defect sites disappeared, presumably ascribed to dehydration reaction of the silicol nests at high temperature. In addition, CH3 absorption bands at 2978, 2883, 1425 and 1381 cm−1 can be observed in the spectra. And the bands at 2938 and 1456 cm−1 are assigned to CH2 absorption bands [28]. The 1742 cm−1 and 1651 cm−1 stretching vibration can be attributed to the CO bonds [28], showing that some adsorbed bidentate propoxy species are converted to CO species. The band at 1550 cm−1 can be assigned to OCO stretching vibrations, further demonstrating that the CO species were carboxylate. And the bands at 1651, 1560, 1456, 1425 and 1381 cm−1 were consistent with CH stretching modes of adsorbed formate and acetate species, as reported by Ruiz et al. [28]. Hence, it can be speculated that the adsorbed bidentate propoxy species transformed into formate and acetate species in the acidic Ti sites. As shown in Fig. 10, the intensities of CH stretching and bending vibration decreased after flushing in N2, indicating that the absorbed carbonous species desorbed. Meanwhile, the intensity of SiOH negative bands weakened, suggesting that the amount of adsorbed species on the catalysts surface decreased probably due to weak adsorption on these Si-OH sites. In contrast, adsorption of PO in Ti-OH sites was irreversible since the intensity of the characteristic bands was constant in the period of the 40-min N2-flush. Strong adsorption of Ti-OH sites showed that adsorbed species were hard to desorb and blocked potential active epoxidation sites, which may be crucial for the deactivation of the catalysts. Fig. 11 shows the spectrum of the Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalyst after introduction of PO in the in-situ cell for 1 h, followed by vacuum pumping for 1 h to remove adsorbed PO. After strong desorption of adsorbed PO, the intensity of the Ti-OH frequency at 3690 cm−1 was partially restored (become less negative), further verifying a fraction of irreversible adsorption on Ti-OH sites. On the contrary, the spectra of SiOH bands were rapidly restored and ultimately seemed to disappear, suggesting the adsorption and desorption of PO on Si-OH sites was completely reversible. Furthermore, CH stretching and bending vibrations vanished, and only the broad bands at 1675 and 1528 cm−1 caused by ν as(CO2−) and ν s(CO2−) of monodentate carbonate, respectively were observed [28]. It should be noted that adsorbed bidentate propoxy groups transformed into formate and acetate species. Afterwards, the species continued to convert to carbonate species strongly adsorbed on Ti-OH sites, which accounted for carbon deposition on the catalysts. The catalysts behavior with respect to deactivation is proposed and explained by the chemical transformations schematically illustrated in Fig. 12 . 3.3.2 Adsorption of propylene The desorption and decomposition spectrum of adsorbed propylene (adsorption time of 1 h) are shown in Fig. 13 . After N2-flush of 40 min, the enhanced negative bands corresponding to Ti-OH sites and silanol nests at defect sites of supports can be observed in the spectra at 3690 and 3541 cm−1, respectively. Compared with the IR spectrum of gas-phase propylene, adsorptions at 3103, 3080, 2986, 2986, 2916, 1401, 1441 and 1478 cm−1 are in agreement with the CH stretching and bending vibrations, and 1644 cm−1 can be identified as CC stretching vibrations. These species all decrease with reaction time in N2. Meanwhile, the increasing bands located at 1743 cm−1 is indicative for CO species. In addition, increasing bands of adsorbed propylene are located in symmetric and asymmetric OCO stretch vibrations at 1557, 1540 and 1513 cm−1. It appears that the transformation from propylene to carboxylate species occurs in acidic Ti sites, and carboxylate species remain to be adsorbed on Ti-OH sites. Subsequently, gas-phase propylene and N2 in the in-situ cell was removed by out-gassing under vacuum for 60 min. The obtained spectra were shown in Fig. 14 . The spectral are very similar to those presented in Fig. 11, only two remaining weak negative bands assigned to Ti-OH sites and silanol nests, and the characteristic bands of carboxylate species at 1675 and 1528 cm−1 are observed. It is therefore proposed that the adsorption of propylene on the catalysts is completely irreversible: a portion of adsorbed propylene is eventually transformed to carboxylate species, strongly adsorbed on Ti-OH sites, which resulted in catalysts deactivation. As indicated in Fig. 15 , we prefer the route of carbonate species formation over the Au catalysts after propylene adsorption. 3.3.3 In-situ reaction To further investigate which surface species causes deactivation of the Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalyst, fresh catalyst was exposed to consecutive cycles of the reaction mixture of 10% propylene, 10% H2, and 10% O2 in 70% N2 at 300 °C for 1 h, followed by N2-flush for 1 h. The resulting spectra are presented in Fig. 16 , apparently quite similar to those obtained after adsorption and decomposition of PO (Fig. 10) and propylene (Fig. 13). In this case, the characteristic peaks of Si-OH sites, Ti-OH sites and silanol nests were located at 3733, 3690 and 3541 cm−1, respectively, in the spectrum. Moreover, the spectrum shows that the characteristic band at 3295 cm−1 is consistent with the formation of H2O. After removal of the reaction mixture, there is likely no significant change in spectrum (Fig. 17 ), compared with the spectra of strong desorption of PO (Fig. 11) and propylene (Fig. 14). Meanwhile, the presence of H2 and O2 did not prevent the generation of carboxylate species, located at 1675 and 1528 cm−1. On the basis of the spectrum of the adsorption of PO and propylene on catalysts, it appears that the interaction between the reaction mixture and Au/meso-Ti-O-Si catalyst can be considered as the result of the combined effect of reactant propylene and product PO. 4 Conclusions Highly dispersed Ti4+ plays a significant role in the epoxidation of propylene, and the presence of Ti-O-Ti clusters and TiO2 is likely to cause deep oxidation, which is bad for the formation of PO. DP urea method is a novel effective way to load Au. The optimized preparation conditions, such as the molar ratio of Au3+/urea of 1/10, the loading temperature of 60 °C and the 0.5 wt.% Au loading, are obtained to assure the dispersion and utilization efficiency of Au NP on the supports. PO and propylene can be irreversibly adsorbed strongly on the catalyst surface and finally transform to carbonate adsorbed on the Ti-OH sites, resulting in catalyst deactivation. PO adsorbed on Ti-OH and Si-OH sites, yielding bidentate propoxy moieties, and then continues to be converted into formate and acetate species in the acidic Ti sites. Unlike PO adsorption, propylene only adsorbed on Ti-OH sites, and adsorbed propylene is first converted into carboxylate species, then further converted to carbonate strongly adsorbed on Ti-OH sites. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the NSFC project (21536010 and 21476187) and the Natural Science Foundation of Fujian Province of China (2015J01059). coredata.dc:description: Highly dispersed Au catalysts supported on amorphous titanosilicate supports with three-dimensional wormhole-like mesoporosity were prepared by deposition–precipitation method, which show excellent performance in propylene epoxidation with H2 and O2. The best catalytic performance, propylene conversion of 12.8%, propylene oxide selectivity of 76.2% and PO space-time yield of 160.9 gpo/Kgcat/h, was obtained at the reaction temperature of 300 °C. The Ti/Si molar ratio of the supports and some experimental parameters, such as the urea amount, loading temperature and Au loading on the as-produced catalyst are optimized. In addition, with the assistance of in-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (In-situ FT-IR), adsorption and desorption of PO, propylene and the reaction mixture on the catalyst are conducted to further explore the deactivation mechanism. It suggests that propylene and PO can be irreversibly and strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface and finally transform to carbonate adsorbed on the active sites Ti-OH, resulting in catalyst deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Activity and stability of titanosilicate supported Au catalyst for propylene epoxidation with H2 and O2
